title: Information on Council expenditure on Non-Disclosure Agreements (NDAs)

content:
Dear Sheffield City Council,
Please provide the following information.
In connection with  NDAs or similarly binding legal or quasi-legal agreements with departing SCC staff:
The total cost figures for the financial years 21-22, 22-23 and 23-24;
The number of staff (no names required) benefiting from such payments in each of those years;
The maximum single payment in each of the years.
Yours faithfully,
Russell Johnson

Dear Russell Johnson,
Thank you for your request for information relating to Information on
Council expenditure on Non-Disclosure Agreements (NDAs) which we received
on 09/04/2024.
Acas explains that a non-disclosure agreement might be used after a
dispute which results in someone leaving a job, to keep details
confidential. That duty of confidentiality applies to both parties,
employer, and former employee. The disclosure of amounts and numbers is
confidential. One couldn’t selectively disclose one amount or all amounts
because that would be a breach of the agreement so signed. You might
consider that there is also a public interest in matters settling without
taking up tribunal time.  That is encouraged by the courts and these types
of agreement are a common way of meeting that public interest. If both we
and the other parties thought that an FOI would result in the Council not
abiding by the agreements, then less cases would settle.
Under section 1(1) of Freedom of Information Act 2000 anyone who requests
information from a public authority is entitled under subsection (a) to be
told if the authority holds the requested information – this is referred
to as the duty to confirm or deny.
However, section 40(5B)(a)(i) of FOIA allows the council to refuse to
confirm or deny that it holds information if the mere act of confirming
(or denying) that information is held would reveal personal data about an
identifiable individual and would contravene one of the data protection
principles.
The two main elements of personal data are that the information must
relate to a living person and that the person must be identifiable.
An identifiable living individual is one who can be identified, directly
or indirectly, by reference to an identifier such as a name, an
identification number, location data, an online identifier or to one or
more factors specific to the physical, physiological, genetic, mental,
economic, cultural, or social identity of the individual.
Information will relate to a person if it is about them, linked to them,
has biographical significance for them, is used to inform decisions
affecting them or has them as its focus.
The council considers that confirming or denying whether the information
is held constitutes the disclosure to the wider world of third-party
personal data. If the council confirmed whether it held information within
scope of the request it would, in effect, confirm whether staff who left
employment in the past three years covered by the scope of the request
signed an NDA.
Further, if the council confirmed or denied it held information, it would,
in effect, confirm whether staff who left the council received
settlements.
On the face of it, the requested information does not directly identify
any individual(s). However, it would be possible to identify individual(s)
because it would be known amongst staff, who had left departments in the
last three years, where their circumstances were not clear.
The council has considered whether the information, when combined with
other information either already in the public domain via personal
knowledge or the grapevine, or known to other people working, may
nevertheless make identification possible.
The council is satisfied that confirming or denying that the information
is held constitutes the disclosure of personal data as specific
individuals could be identified and it would disclose whether those
individuals had signed an NDA or received a settlement.
The council has next considered whether confirming or denying that the
information is held would contravene one of the data protection
principles.
In the case of a FOIA request, the personal data is processed when it is
disclosed in response to the request. This means that the information can
only be disclosed – or as in this case, the council can only confirm
whether or not it holds the requested information - if to do so would be:
a. lawful (i.e. it would meet one of the conditions of lawful processing
listed in Article 6(1) UK GDPR); b. fair; and c. transparent.
To be lawful, one of the lawful bases listed in Article 6(1) of the UK
GDPR must apply to the processing. It must also be lawful. In considering
any legitimate interest(s) in the disclosure of the requested information
under FOIA, or confirmation or denial that it is held, the council
recognises that a wide range of interests may be legitimate interests.
They can be the requester’s own interests or the interests of third
parties, and commercial interests as well as wider societal benefits.
These interest(s) can include broad general principles of accountability
and transparency for their own sakes, as well as case specific interests.
The council considers that any individuals who may have been involved have
a strong and reasonable expectation that personal information about them
will remain confidential in accordance with data protection laws.
We understand the interest of citizens. But we must consider whether the
disclosure is necessary. ‘Necessary’ means more than desirable but less
than indispensable or absolute necessity. Accordingly, the test is one of
reasonable necessity and involves consideration of alternative measures
which may make disclosure of the requested information unnecessary.
Disclosure under FOIA must therefore be the least intrusive means of
achieving the legitimate aim in question.
The council appreciates that there is a public interest. However, there is
also a public interest in upholding standard practice in HR matters, which
is to observe a duty of confidentiality. The council has therefore decided
in this case that confirmation or denial is not necessary to meet the
legitimate interest in disclosure. As confirmation or denial is not
necessary, there is no lawful basis for this processing, and it is
unlawful.
If you have any queries about this response, please do not hesitate to
contact us.
The information provided in this response is available for re-use under
the terms of the Open Government Licence v3.0. The terms of the OGL can be
found [1]here. When re-using the information, Sheffield City Council
requires you to include the following attribution statement: “Contains
public sector information obtained from Sheffield City Council and
licensed under the Open Government Licence v3.0.”
If you are unhappy with the response you have received in relation to your
request, you are entitled to have this reviewed. You can ask for an
internal review by replying to this email. Internal review requests should
be submitted within 40 working days from the date of this response.
If you remain dissatisfied with the outcome of your internal review, you
can contact the Information Commissioner’s Office. Please see
[2]
https://ico.org.uk/make-a-complaint/offi...
for further details.
Yours sincerely,
Sheffield City Council
PO Box 1283
Sheffield, S1 1UJ

Dear Sheffield City Council,
Please pass this on to the person who conducts Freedom of Information reviews.
I am writing to request an internal review of Sheffield City Council's handling of my FOI request 'Information on Council expenditure on Non-Disclosure Agreements (NDAs)'.
Please review this decision, as none  of the information I have requested is personal data. I would be grateful if you could release the information which does not fall under this description.
I do not accept that release of the anonymous and aggregated data would create such risk of identification of individual recipients of gagging payments that the public interest argument is overridden.
A full history of my FOI request and all correspondence is available on the Internet at this address:
https://www.whatdotheyknow.com/request/i...
Yours faithfully,
Russell Johnson

Dear Mr Johnson,
You have asked us for an internal review of your request on 9^th May 2024.
This has now been carried out and our detailed response is below. This was
carried out by a member of the FOI team from 13^th – 21^st May 2024. Text
that forms part of our original response is shown in blue, to aid
understanding.
Your Request Received 9/4/2024
Please provide the following information.
In connection with NDAs or similarly binding legal or quasi-legal
agreements with departing SCC staff:
The total cost figures for the financial years 21-22, 22-23 and 23-24;
The number of staff (no names required) benefiting from such payments in
each of those years; The maximum single payment in each of the years.
Our Response Sent 8/5/2024
We replied, citing section 40(5B)(a)(i) of FOIA which allows the council
to refuse to confirm or deny that it holds information if the mere act of
confirming (or denying) that information is held would reveal personal
data about an identifiable individual and would contravene one of the data
protection principles.
Further explanation, given in our response:
The council considers that confirming or denying whether the information
is held constitutes the disclosure to the wider world of third-party
personal data. If the council confirmed whether it held information within
scope of the request it would, in effect, confirm whether staff who left
employment in the past three years covered by the scope of the request
signed an NDA.
Further, if the council confirmed or denied it held information, it would,
in effect, confirm whether staff who left the council received
settlements.
On the face of it, the requested information does not directly identify
any individual(s). However, it would be possible to identify individual(s)
because it would be known amongst staff, who had left departments in the
last three years, where their circumstances were not clear.
The council has considered whether the information, when combined with
other information either already in the public domain via personal
knowledge or the grapevine, or known to other people working, may
nevertheless make identification possible.
The council is satisfied that confirming or denying that the information
is held constitutes the disclosure of personal data as specific
individuals could be identified and it would disclose whether those
individuals had signed an NDA or received a settlement.
We further considered the lawful basis for revealing this data under UK
GDPR, and were satisfied that to do so would breach data protection law in
that the individuals involved would have the reasonable expectation of
privacy.
We also considered the public interest in knowing how the local authority
is spending funds and how many times such agreements were used:
The council appreciates that there is a public interest. However, there is
also a public interest in upholding standard practice in HR matters, which
is to observe a duty of confidentiality. The council has therefore decided
in this case that confirmation or denial is not necessary to meet the
legitimate interest in disclosure. As confirmation or denial is not
necessary, there is no lawful basis for this processing, and it is
unlawful.
Further stating:
You might consider that there is also a public interest in matters
settling without taking up tribunal time. That is encouraged by the courts
and these types of agreement are a common way of meeting that public
interest. If both we and the other parties thought that an FOI would
result in the Council not abiding by the agreements, then less cases would
settle.
Response following Internal Review
The staff member who dealt with the original request carefully checked and
considered the legal implications. They felt the council’s common law duty
of confidentiality should take precedence over other interests and failure
to observe this could lead to an actionable breach of confidence.
In conducting this review, I have reconsidered, checked the legal
position, and formed the view that it would be unlawful to reveal, not
only the financial information pertaining to the agreements, but also
confirming the existence of them could lead to the identification of the
staff in question. This would be especially likely where there has been a
high-profile departure. It could also lead to individuals being
erroneously linked with financial settlements. In addition, I have
confirmed that the numbers of staff who may be offered such agreements is
low, and this would make identification more likely for the individuals in
question.
Advice and Assistance
Under section 16, Freedom of Information Act 2000, we have a duty to
provide advice and assistance. In our reply, we did not indicate that some
of the information you requested is, or will be, in the public domain.
Information about exit payments is supplied to central government and
published here: [1]Local authority exit payments, England, 2014-15 to
2020-21 - GOV.UK (www.gov.uk) and [2]Live tables on local government
finance - GOV.UK (www.gov.uk) for the years 2021-22 and 2022-23.
Our audited accounts for 2023-24 are not yet available so has not been
supplied at this time. We shall make a return to central government in due
course, and it is possible that relevant information may be published at
the above link.
Points to Note
The government information shown gives the number of ex-gratia payments
made and the total amount although not the highest payments made. You will
note that some information has been redacted ‘to protect confidentiality’,
denoted by [c]. You will see that other public authorities also show
redacted information, which aims to ensure that individuals are not
identified.
The government ‘metadata’ tab explains the information more fully, but
includes the following:
·      Where fewer than five exit payment packages were awarded, all other
data for the category has been suppressed.
• Where fewer than five exit payment packages including ex gratia and /
or other payments were awarded, only the total value of all exit
packages, the number of all exit packages and the mean cost of all
exit packages are shown.
• Additional suppression of data has been applied where only one local
authority / class of authority would otherwise be suppressed to ensure
the suppressed figure cannot be deduced from the Total.
This government collated data is not the exact information you have
requested and shows aggregated figures for all termination payments
regardless of whether a ‘non-disclosure’ or confidentiality clause exists
within the agreement. However, it does give the total value of payments,
which is what you have requested.
Conclusion
We consider that we were correct to apply section 40(5B)(a)(i) of FOIA to
information relating to your request for the numbers of staff and maximum
single payments in each of the years 2021-24.
We should have considered our duties under s16 and offered the advice and
assistance, directing you to where the total cost of payments, including
settlements that may be relevant to your inquiry have been published. This
has now been rectified and advice and assistance given above.
If you are dissatisfied with the outcome of this review, you can make a
complaint to the Information Commissioner’s Office:
